results.title: The World of Andrew Wyeth
results.creator_credit: A Schwartz-Wallace Production, Al Schwartz and Hal Wallace
results.brief_description: An examination of the work of American painter Andrew Wyeth. Over thirty-five paintings are shown. Blending the subjects of the artist’s representational style painting with actual scenes from the Pennsylvania and Maine countryside. The artist’s special vision and technique make the lonely countryside, and gnarled people uniquely his.

results.title: The World of 'The dark crystal'
results.brief_description:
Indicates the enormous amount of skill and teamwork required to put together the puppet film ‘The dark crystal’ which was five years in the making. Shows the building of the sets from artists’ impressions, the creation of the individual puppet characters and the training of the puppet operators who used video monitors to observe the puppets’ movements as they worked.
Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The World Meteorological Organization
results.creator_credit: Krishna Singh, V.R. Sarma and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The United Nations: Its Charter and Organization”.
Traces the history of the World meteorological Organization - a Genva based Specialised Agency of the United Nations. Describes the activities and functions of the organization and explains its role as a co-ordinating body in study of weather phenomena.

results.title: The World Is Watching
results.creator_credit: Investigative Productions Inc, TV Ontario, Channel 4 Television Corporation, Great Britain, Ikon TV, Holland, Sveriges TV, Sweden, Harold Crooks, Jim Monro and Peter Raymont
results.brief_description: Cameraman Don Holmberg and award-winning independent Canadian director, Peter Raymont, covered peace talks in Nicaragua, November 1987. What they saw, and what was reported on television networks in the US and Europe was quite different.

results.title: The World is round. - [Abridged version]
results.brief_description: A film about an organization called Canada World Youth, which brings together young people from Canada and developing countries in Latin America, Asia and Africa. They live and work in an atmosphere of international fellowship and understanding. An NFB camera crew circled the globe, filming the program in Canada, Guatemala, Senegal, and Malaysia. The film tells of the rich and colorful experiences of the participants in this unique experience.

results.title: The World is rich
results.creator_credit: Films of Fact and Paul Rotha
results.brief_description: A documentary using footage from around the world, shot over a 30 year period. It shows that the world’s potential food resources are sufficient to supply the world population with an adequate diet. Anarchy in production and distribution, outdated and wasteful agricultural methods, black marketing and food speculation in food are causing famine in many countries, while in others “surplus” food is stored unused or burned. Illustrates how, given a sane economic system, food distribution and production could be geared to the actual needs of the entire world population.

results.title: The World is our sound toy
results.creator_credit: Dylan Davis and Swinburne University of Technology
results.brief_description:
The sound toys presented in this interactive work create a computing experience that extends the imagination not only in a musical sense but in the way we perceive the world around us. They explore the nature musical software, the use of the environment as musical instruments and look to explore a musical interpretation of the environment around us. The sound toys and the inspiration behind each one include:
The Leaf blower - the desire to turn the day-to-day noise pollution into musical instruments
The Bird chorus - waiting for the tram at the bottom of Elizabeth St. As I looked up at all the birds on the cables, they sat in a set of patterns that lent itself to a musical sequence
The Sea gulls - watching the seagulls descend on the MCG 30 minutes before the final whistle
Windows - peering in office windows and trying to imagine what is going on inside
Telegraph lines - driving to Sydney on the Hume Highway
Jam tarts - old analogue sequences. the jam tart image is from historic Gundagai, from the old bakery there
Palm leaf - camping in Mungo Brush National park in New South Wales
Big poles - cloudy rainy day at Mungo Brush National Park, staring at the ducks and the poles in the water
Ghoulies - accurately time mapped, thus allowing a BPM counter

results.title: The World is not enough (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Featuring the longest pre credit sequence in the Bond franchise, “The World is not enough” has more than one fiendish villain and a start including a knife throwing sniper, a brief interlude, then an extended powerboat chase on the Thames followed by a hot air balloon. British oil tycoon Sir Robert King is killed via a booby trap at MI6 by a terrorist, thought to be Renard the Anarchist (Robert Carlyle) - an ex KGB agent whose only goal is to create chaos. His claim to fame is a bullet permanently lodged in his head, killing off his senses as well as any feeling of pain, effectively making him super-human. Renard was also responsible for the kidnapping of King’s daughter Elektra (Sophie Marceau) and Bond is sent to protect her and to find the traitor on staff. A ploy is uncovered to steal an atomic missile and use it for sabotage. Nuclear scientist Dr Christmas Jones (Denise Richards) assists Bond is the retrieval process, as well as providing Bond with another potential conquest. Notorious for being the last film in which Q (Desmond Llewelyn) appears, we also see a more humanised M (Judi Dench) and a dazzling array of inventive chase sequences.

results.title: The World Health Organization at work
results.brief_description: The work of the United Nations World Health Organization in the battle against disease. Tuberculosis was the cause of many deaths in Istanbul, but the government lacked the resources to attack the problem. The World Heath Organization assisted the government to set up a model demonstration and training centre for the fight against the disease. In Israel the WHO is helping to control the spread of rabies. In the desert area around the United States Mexican border an epidemic of rabies broke out, meaning cattle as well as people. With help and advice from the WHO, experienced hunters and trappers were sent out to trap the rabid animals.

results.title: The World famous Cathedral of Chatres: miracle of the 11th century
results.brief_description: A study of the famous gothic Cathedral of Chatres noted for its wealth of sculpture and magnificent stained glass windows. The film includes detailed studies of statuary and architectural features of the cathedral.
